awd_titl_txt: The Mechanisms that Drive Summer Teleconnections: Patterns Associated with High Surface Temperatures
awd_abstract_narration:
The large-scale atmospheric circulation is characterized by circumpolar flows that navigate around high- and low-pressure centers distributed across the globe. This circulation varies in time, ranging from a few days to well over decades. When averaged over a season, the climatological circulation features appear fixed geographically as stationary waves of constant amplitudes. Within a season, the large-scale atmospheric circulation can be thought of as comprising of these stationary waves and evolving patterns that deviate from them (i.e., anomalies). The recurring and persistent anomalous patterns are referred to as teleconnection patterns. They can appear naturally as a part of our chaotic atmospheric system and can be excited by events like sustained regional heating over the unusually warm ocean surface. The interference between teleconnection patterns and the attendant stationary waves can intensify high- and low-pressure centers leading to extreme weather and climate events such as droughts and floods as well as unseasonably cold and warm spells. In recent decades, the occurrence of summertime extreme events has increased and its attribution to global warming is unclear. To date, the mechanisms behind the excitation and maintenance of the summertime teleconnection patterns are not well understood.
 
This proposal aims to understand the physical mechanisms that excite summer teleconnection patterns associated with extreme surface temperature signatures. The investigators hypothesize that the inter-decadal increase in the heat wave frequency has coincided with an increased occurrence of particular teleconnection patterns (initiated by diabatic heating) during the boreal summer. The investigators plan to examine the possible impact of interference between these teleconnections and stationary waves on surface temperature. They will assess if there has been any long term (greater than a decade) changes in the frequency and intensity of the summer teleconnection patterns and, if so, explore possible causes of these long-term changes. The research methods include cluster analysis of the combined upper tropospheric geopotential height and surface air temperature fields, various diagnostic analyses of the resulting cluster patterns, surface energy budget analysis, and numerical modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: The scientific objectives of this proposal were to advance our understanding of how global-scale circulation patterns are related to summer heat wave events. The working hypothesis was that the more frequent occurrence of heat wave events over Europe and North America in recent decades during the meteorological boreal summer coincided with the occurrence of certain global-scale circulation patterns. Under this general theme, the investigations supported by this award yielded several major discoveries. Here, two topics are described that the PIs believe would be of particular interest for a broad audience. 

The first outcome is that a heat wave event is more likely to occur when there is a slowly propagating, large spatial scale, wavy circulation pattern present. The spatial scale is about the size of western Europe and the propagation speed relative to the ground is essentially zero. This wavy feature is most evident in the upper troposphere, about 8 km above the ground.  This slowly moving, quasi-stationary wave is forced by latent heating upstream of the wave and the region of extreme heat. Latent heating is generated when water vapor condenses to form clouds. In the case of European heat waves, the hotspots for the latent heating are located over the North Sea and the Caspian Sea.  For these heat waves, the surface temperature increase was caused mostly by solar radiation. In contrast, for the southwestern US, heat waves were caused by a reduction of evaporative cooling caused by drier soil conditions. Previous research by others have shown that these drier soil conditions are caused by a lack of rain during those winters that precede the summer extreme heat events. 

 

For the second outcome, our analysis showed that the winters that precede summers with heat waves have sea surface temperature (SST) patterns that resemble La Niña, with warmer than usual SSTs in the western tropical Pacific and colder than usual SSTs in the central and eastern tropical Pacific. This finding is consistent with the existing knowledge that the US southwest is drier during La Niña years. Therefore, the cause of the more frequent occurrence of La Niña-like SST patterns in recent decades was investigated. This is an important topic for both scientists and the public at large because the tropical SST pattern impacts the weather and climate globally. This observed trend is opposite to the projections made by the current generation of climate models which, in general, predict El Niño-like SST trends. Adopting a theoretical approach, the equation for mixed layer thermodynamic energy balance was used to estimate the leading order SST pattern response to horizontally uniform forcing from the atmosphere. This approach was applied to both climate model output and observational data. The mixed layer refers to the top layer of the ocean in which temperature (or density) is close to being uniform with depth. This assumption of horizontally uniform warming can be justified because greenhouse gases are well mixed in the atmosphere. The spatial variation of the estimated SST response to this horizontally uniform forcing is determined by the horizontal variation of the longtime mean wind speed and SST pattern. The investigation revealed that the estimated leading order SST response shows warming in a broad swath of the western tropical Pacific and a smaller region in the eastern edge of the tropical Pacific, and cooling in the central-eastern tropical Pacific. This estimated SST pattern closely resembles the observed SST pattern. This result therefore suggests that the observed SST trend pattern over the past several decades is caused in part by greenhouse gas warming. The future tropical Pacific SST change may not follow the same path because there are other factors that are not considered in this leading order estimate. However, the result is useful for various stake holders for their decision making. 

 Broader Impacts: The project partially supported four graduate students. The outcome of the proposed research will help to reduce the uncertainties in long-term climate prediction of the global-scale surface temperature and circulation patterns. The PI and co-PI also engaged with a teacher and students from Bald Eagle Area High School in a rural Pennsylvania school district. The students performed research using authentic meteorological data in their advanced computer science class led by Mr. Max Besong. The students presented their research findings at a poster session at Penn State where they had the opportunity to interact with faculty members and graduate students. This poster session was followed by an afternoon workshop led by the PI, co-PI, and Mr. Besong.
